Perhaps this horse is dead, but I'll beat it again.

Most of the comments are about quality control at the website. Jim, I understand this is not your responsibility. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be anyone's responsibility. And that just won't fly.

Does this have to become the publisher's personal concern before someone will address the problem?

Michigan - Michigan St. played an out door hockey game in the Michigan bowl setting an attendance record of 113,000 +.  This is a dome game and as said earlier the Giants could have made it in easily and had 4 hours before game.  WTHIGO!

15-20" of snow around town. Severe drifting with 30 mph winds. Yes, the Giants should have left Friday as all of this was predicted well in advance, but the roof concerns because the weight of the snow is a whole other matter.  The roof has been damaged in the past from a severe snow storm. We don't want it coming down with a full house during the game.
OK, but no one is giving Pettitte a 7 year deal either.

I must have missed something. The Yankees went down 1-2-3 in the first inning of every game of the ALCS. Their offense never showed up, except for Cano. Their manager chose to pitch Pettitte against Lee, a pitcher who was in their heads from the previous year, instead of throwing Burnett, who was unlikely to win in any case. Their pitching in the ALCS was not why they lost: certainly a lot of late runs were given up by the bullpen pitchers who would not have been pitching if the Yankees had had a LEAD.

Poor strategy in game 4 to throw Burnett, and Derek Jeter going 0 for 6 at leadoff, had much more to do with losing than pitching, which was always pitching in a hole. The Yankees need a sparkplug up top; hopefully they miss out on Lee and either promote Gardner to #1 (Jeter as a contact hitter could be a good #2) or sign a David Eckstein/Chuck Knoblauch type who can annoy opposing pitchers, work walks, steal bases, and get the following hitters some better pitches to hit. Even Cliff Lee pitches worse out of the stretch.

We stayed at Sultanahmet Palace and right from the very moment we reached the hotel, we felt at home....we were greeted by the young and amazingly hospitable team of young professionals receptionist MehmetAli, Mahmut and Celal from the hotel staff. All of them have been extremely helpful, cheerful, friendly and spent a lot of time with us advising on the things to do as we had only 3 days and had to pack in a lot. The entire staff made our stay and the overall maiden experience to Istanbul a memorable one.
If you are looking for a hotel (not so commercial, and small in size) and wanting a cozy experience, where you are made to feel at home, in the heart of the old city and literally a stones throw from Hagiaye Sofia, Blue mosque and Topkapi palace....we strongly recommend this place. The room was also very spacious, light, modern and very clean. Breakfast was very good and they even have tea time for all the guests every evening where you are served free tea and cakes!

Don't bother looking any further for a hotel .. Book Hotel SULTANAHMET PALACE now! .. you will not be disappointed. We intend to come back to Istanbul again in the future and we will certainly stay here. Only small issue was the quality of satellite TV channels which were not so good as many of the channels do not work, however who cares about TV when you are in such a magnificient city that has so much to offer.
Food Tip at hOtel : Vegeterians would love the dearth of overalleggies options in Istanbul, S.PALACE's vegeterian mezze platter is something worth trying...
http://www.sultanahmetpalace.com/
Thanks again to all the staff at Hotel Sultanahmet apart. Other hotels can learn a lot from you about high levels of service and free flowing good will gestures. We hope you remain the same in years to come. keep up the good work as it is really appreciated by your guests.

Food tips for vegeterians:
Cafe RAM? close to Hotel , offers a nice variety of vegeterian options, do not miss the Imam Bayaldi.
http://ramirestaurant.com/eng

It is a crime that we don't pay for organ donation. No transplants are possible without an organ, yet we speak of paying the donor as immoral. Yet everyone else in the medical process get paid. This is actually a way of saving money and being cheap. Our basic resource is our body. Why should it be immoral to get paid for it?
If people were eligible to receive an organ only if they have been a registered donor for the preceding 5 years, it would encourage people to register themselves and their children as donors now.

Supply and demand will lead to criminal abuse and those better off financially survive and the rest die. A far better solution would be to have a significant tax for anyone who is not registered as a donor (except for real religious issues) and a significant tax credit for those who are registered to donate. Yes, the people left behind would either be penalized or rewarded by the decision of the person who died but they would also be far less inclined to prevent the donations.

It is criminal that so many organs are buried or burned when they could be saving peoples lives. It is amazing and frightening how poorly informed people are about their own religions position on the subject. People are simply sad when they try to make up valid excuses for not being registered.

Hit their family where they care the most in their money pocket, a tax credit or a tax penalty can be real incentives especially if the penalty is many times the credit. Unfortunately many people have to be paid to do the right think. Everyone should be happy and proud to register to donate their organs. The donation only happens when a persons life is over and they are no longer using the organs anyway.

I am both registered and I have already donated 70% of my liver in a live donation to save a life and I hope that when I die (we all will) that maybe my organs can save another 5 or 6 or more lives. Time to recycle and show the world that Americans are really caring and dynamic people. And the government should make the registration process as simple as possible with online signatures and any other easy legal method. But never leave it to supply and demand because it will corrupt and destroy the integrity of the transplant process.

I am registered with New York State to be an organ donor in the event of my death if feasible. The reason so few people offer their organs to save the lives of others is that they are primitive.

Signing up as an organ donor is liberating, scientific, and rational. Those unwilling to do this are selfish and contemptible.

Selling organs is an old far-right conservative market-based idea that people like Gary Becker came up with as part of their belief that the free market is a panacea for everything.

The only problem is the facts. When people buy organs, the result is disaster and explotation of the poor. The rich can afford it but the poor can't.

The Journal of the American Medical Association published an article by public health workers describing how organ sales worked in Pakistan, and the New York Times Magazine followed it up by sending a reporter to Pakistan for a journalistic version of the story, interviewing some of the actual people (usually women) who sold kidneys.

Overwhelmingly, women who sold kidneys wound up getting less money than they were promised, or no money at all. They were given no followup care. They were often too weak to work, so instead of making a small amount of money they lost their entire lifetime earning capacity. The usual purpose for selling an organ was to pay off debts, but they usually didn't make enough to do so and wound up further behind. If they got kidney failure later in their life they wouldn't be able to afford dialysis, much less a transplant, so they would just die.

Gary Becker wants to be able to buy organs if he needs them, because he's rich, rather than having to give or get them from a relative. Most advocates for organ sales are rich. They want to take care of themselves without having to worry about the rest of us.
People who do not volunteer to donate their organs upon death should not be eligible to receive one. It is that simple.

"You’ve got only one liver but you don’t really need that meaty chunk at the end. How does $30,000 sound?"

it depends on how much wealth i already have. if i have already accumulated a large amount of wealth, i probably don't need the additional $30,000 very much. however, if i am poor and desperate through chance or unfairness (another form of chance, i guess), then the $30,000 would sound very nice. it also depends on my ability to reason about benefits ($30,000 + psychological warm feelings from altruism) and costs ($?).

for similar reasons, i would think that poor women and men (with little physical wealth or "human capital"--Mr. Becker's term) would have a greater incentive to explicitly or implicitly sell sex or to marry a wealth spouse, but wealthy people have less of a need to do so.

if we are going to legalize the sale of bodily organs before or after death, maybe we should also consider legalizing the sale of sex (and hair). if people can reason about the benefits and costs of organ sales, can we also reason about the benefits and costs of sex sales? it might be difficult especially for those with little "human capital" and little time or ability to reason in this regard.

My mother was able to donate only her corneas, but that was important for her and for the rest of the family.  My father, always listed as an organ donor, learned that his organs probably would not be taken (he was too old and too sick) so he became a cadaver donor to our university's medical school.  First year medical students are assigned one cadaver per team and they work with that body for the full year - it's often referred to as their "first patient."  Once the med school was finished with him, they cremated my father and returned his cremains to me.  He was pleased that he was able to continue contributing to education even after he died.  So were we.

What about the fact that people in Arizona-who played by the rules, standing in line  waiting for a scarce organ only to  find that the state cut them off from the funds necessary to have the transplant operation?  I fear that the process of making more organs available will also deepen the hold of a market system approach to health care in the U.S. that already favors those with heavier wallets way too much.  The vaunted "death panels" that Sarah Palin alluded to in her fight against the recent  health reform law already exist.  Those that cannot pay for healthcare-poor children, the unemployed, and those who just do not earn enough to have good insurance already feel the force of the "market."  Third world countries already have citizens who have sold their organs on the black market.  We already are getting so little in terms of real preventative health care when one thinks of what is spent.  I really distrust the central thesis of this article:  that the "market" would   be able to regulate the process of organ donation in a way that would not value those people who have more money as being "more equal" than those who do not, or would not encourage poor people to sell parts of themselves to those richer than they are-a nightmare scenario that we do not seem very far from, judging from the on-going spectacle of patients who are not deemed "worth" a transplant operation dying in Arizona.   The inhumanity implicit in our current health care "system" is stunning.  I fear that this inhumanity will soon extend to encouraging poor people to barter their bodies for the social security that the U.S. now seems determined to deny to its citizens.  What makes this lack of compassion even more stark is the fact one can now cut taxes on the richest people in society, and then spend millions of dollars on endless war,  while at the same time asserting that one cannot 'afford' to support the growing ranks of the poor, or to improve education, or to support workers.  I fear that all too soon, the spectacle of those dying from the lack of transplant operation will change to the spectacle of people dying from botched donation operations, or from conditions made worse when they felt the pressure to donate an organ-to avoid homelessness, or to eat another day.

The writer says this about his cousin: "At age 37, he got a new heart. Counting the one he was born with, it is his fourth." How is it that the cousin has managed to go through three hearts before this? If there is a shortage, wouldn't it make more sense that everyone who needs one gets only one shot at a spare?

Tell Miss Nieves to get herself to the Texas Heart Institute. The newest Ventricular Assist Devices promise twenty or more years of function.

I predict the Organ Recovery Teams are going to be a flop. They sound too much like body snatchers hovering over the poor and the unlucky. Not that there's anything wrong with it. Personally, I am an organ donor and I support opt-out vs the current opt-in system.

Although I have a vested interest, I believe that if you recieve benefits from the State then it's fair to expect you to contribute, whether it's participating in well vetted, safe clinical trials or donating your organs.
sooner or later the real cam newton will show up and his trophy will sit next to reggies

If a kid like Andrew Luck doesn't finish college, why would we even pretend anymore that NCAA Div. I football is anything more than a semi pro league, with sham connections to academic institutions?  I would rather an amateur league just start up already, take kids right out of high school who don't want to go to or graduate from college, and compete with colleges for players, while actually paying them, WHILE THEY ARE PLAYING AND PREPARING FOR THE PRO DRAFT.  Why hasn't some entrepreneur started a league to recruit the best players out of high school?  Why do colleges and universities have this monopoly?  Why should these young men have to pose as students for two or three years, when they can just as well say "I need to do what's best for my family" at 18?  It didn't teach LeBron manners, but it's honest.  After all the years minor leagues have been the norm in baseball, what are we waiting for?  Cam Newton represents no college or academic tradition.  I know his name, I have no idea where he "goes to school".
